item.title: Trump’s Likely Labor Pick, Andrew Puzder, Is Critic of Minimum Wage Increases
item.media:description: Andrew F. Puzder at Trump Tower in Manhattan on Wednesday.
item.description: Mr. Puzder, chief executive of the company behind Hardee’s and Carl’s Jr., also strongly supports repealing the Affordable Care Act.
item.dc:creator: NOAM SCHEIBER and MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: Worried Auto Industry Braces for Change Under Trump
item.media:description: Robots make welds on metal frames for the Ford Escape sport utility vehicle at an assembly plant in Louisville, Ky. Ford said it would keep production of a Lincoln S.U.V. in the United States. President-elect Donald J. Trump has criticized the company for its investments in Mexico.
item.description: Tariffs on imported vehicles and parts and fewer subsidies for electric cars are among the possible changes that concern domestic automakers.
item.dc:creator: BILL VLASIC

item.title: Donald Trump Is Said to Intend to Keep a Stake in His Business
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump at Trump Tower on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: The president-elect is said to be considering turning over his company to his two adult sons, but planning to resist calls to divest.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN and JO BECKER

item.title: The Comet Ping Pong Gunman Answers Our Reporter’s Questions
item.media:description: Edgar M. Welch surrendered to the police in Washington on Sunday.
item.description: A soft-spoken Edgar M. Welch described from jail his thoughts leading up to his decision to fire a military-style assault rifle inside the pizzeria.
item.dc:creator: ADAM GOLDMAN

item.title: California Today: California Today: Booksellers See a Threat in New Law
item.media:description: City Lights Bookstore in San Francisco. Some booksellers are worried about new legislation intended to curb fake collectibles.
item.media:credit: Kevin Miyazaki for The New York Times
item.description: Thursday: A complication for autographed book sales, the next class of California political leaders, and a huge sigh of relief after surgery for conjoined twins.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: As Fake News Spreads Lies, More Readers Shrug at the Truth
item.media:description: Larry Laughlin, a retired business owner from Minnesota, said he felt alienated from conventional news media.
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.description: Fake news has become a partisan tool, but people differ widely on their ability to discern what is real and what is fabrication.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Grandiose Ideas for Donald Trump Inaugural Give Way to Traditional
item.media:description: Construction on the presidential reviewing stand, where President-elect Donald J. Trump will view the inaugural parade, on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington.
item.description: A parade up Fifth Avenue? A helicopter ride to Washington from New York? Both are dismissed as unrealistic, especially given security concerns.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN and NICHOLAS FANDOS

item.title: Transition Briefing: Labor secretary pick may rekindle Trump’s women problem. And Chris Christie won’t head Republican Party.
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump toured the Carrier plant in Indianapolis last week.
item.description: The president-elect’s attitude toward women has been a problematic political issue for a long time. With the tapping of fast-food executive Andrew F. Puzder, look for more questions to emerge.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: South Korea’s President Awaits Her Fate, Dejected, Sleepless and Alone
item.media:description: About 1.7 million people protested in central Seoul on Saturday, calling for Ms. Park to step down.
item.description: As her presidency crumbles, Park Geun-hye has been cloistered in the presidential palace and is rarely seen in public.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Claims Against South Korean President: Extortion, Abuse of Power and Bribery
item.media:description: A protest in Seoul, South Korea, on Saturday calling for President Park Geun-hye to step down.
item.description: Ahead of Friday’s impeachment vote, here are the accusations against President Park Geun-hye, which she has dismissed as a “house of cards.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Defiance and Disillusionment in Heartland of South Korean President’s Support
item.media:description: In what appeared to be a last-ditch effort to court her remaining supporters, President Park Geun-hye visited Daegu, South Korea, last week, making a rare public appearance after a fire destroyed part of a market.
item.description: Unlike the vast majority of South Koreans, some in Daegu, a city where President Park Geun-hye has deep political roots, see her as an innocent victim of a scandal.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: 59 Rescues in 2016; Witness the Last
item.description: Aboard the Bourbon Argos on its final rescue mission of the year with members of Doctors Without Borders, aiding African migrants in the Mediterranean Sea.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: Great Performers | Don Cheadle
item.description: Step into the world of "L.A. Noir" through a series of nine groundbreaking virtual-reality films starring the year’s best actors — and you, the viewer.

item.title: Pursuits: Ann Patchett’s Guide for Bookstore Lovers
item.media:description: Ann Patchett at her bookstore, Parnassus Books, in Nashville, with one of her shop dogs.
item.description: If bookstores are a must on your travel itinerary, Ann Patchett has a road map for you.
item.dc:creator: ANN PATCHETT

item.title: Can You Get Too Much Protein?
item.description: While some nutritionists have encouraged the protein craze, a number of experts are urging caution.
item.dc:creator: RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: The Oakland Fire: Delving Into What Happened, and Why
item.media:description: A sidewalk memorial to the victims of the warehouse fire last week in Oakland, Calif.
item.description: The Times is doing something new: Our reporters who are investigating the devastating blaze will be providing regular updates on their findings. And we’re asking readers for help.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Oakland Fire Victims Included Performers and Educators
item.media:description: A memorial near the site of the fire in Oakland, Calif.
item.description: As the coroner began releasing the victims’ names, friends and family members remembered their loved ones as “honorable” and “ferociously brilliant.”
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER and NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: On Campus, Trump Fans Say They Need ‘Safe Spaces’
item.media:description: Amanda Delekta, 20, the political director for the College Republicans at the University of Michigan, in her bedroom near campus in Ann Arbor, Mich., last week.
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.description: Republican students feel estranged from colleges where the institutional bias leans left, and university officials fear tensions will increase after the inauguration.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

item.title: Cuba’s Surge in Tourism Keeps Food Off Residents’ Plates
item.media:description: Workers in a lettuce field this past week at a farm in Alamar, outside Havana.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Consumption by visitors — nearly 3.5 million last year — is overwhelming supplies and raising prices, forcing families to make do with even less than usual.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: The Best Albums of 2016
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Beyoncé, David Bowie, Anohni, Mary Halvorson, Andrew Cyrille and Chance the Rapper.
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Andrew Harnik/Associated Press; Andrew H. Walker/Getty Images; Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times; Jacob Blickenstaff for The New York Times; Laurel Golio for The New York Times; Michael Zorn/Invision, via Associated Press
item.description: Beyoncé and Bowie, Chance the Rapper and Radiohead, Frank Ocean and Leonard Cohen — and much, much more.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA and NATE CHINEN

item.title: The Best Songs of 2016
item.media:description: Beyoncé’s “Lemonade,” an ambitious album and film, tackled issues of race and infidelity, and its release became the kind of all-consuming cultural phenomenon that perhaps no artist but Beyoncé could muster.
item.description: The music critics of The New York Times share their picks for the best songs of the year.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA and NATE CHINEN

item.title: Hundreds of U.K. Police Officers Said to Have Sexually Abused Vulnerable People
item.media:description: Officers in London. A report found that there had been 436 accusations of police sexual abuse in England and Wales over the two years ending in March.
item.description: A report by a national watchdog found that domestic abuse victims, drug and alcohol addicts and people who work in the sex industry had been targeted.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Guitarist/singer Greg Lake of Emerson, Lake and Palmer Dies
item.description: Musician Greg Lake co-founded both King Crimson and Emerson, Lake and Palmer — bands that helped define the sprawling, influential but often-maligned genre known as progressive rock.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Heart-Rending Testimony as Dylann Roof Trial Opens
item.media:description: Dylann S. Roof at a court hearing in Charleston, S.C., in July 2015.
item.description: Mr. Roof, 22, is accused of killing nine people at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C. He faces the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: KEVIN SACK and ALAN BLINDER

item.title: Burst Radiator Blamed for Deaths of 2 Sisters in the Bronx
item.media:description: Ibanez Ambrose, 2, top, and Scylee Vayoh Ambrose, 1, who died from severe burns on Wednesday apparently after a steam radiator malfunctioned in their apartment in the Bronx.
item.description: Ibanez Ambrose, 2, and Scylee Vayoh Ambrose, 1, died in temporary housing for the homeless after being severely burned, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: RICK ROJAS and NIKITA STEWART

item.title: Donald Trump Is Time’s Person of the Year, to No One’s Surprise
item.media:description: During a news conference at a Manhattan hotel in July, Donald J. Trump announced that Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana would be his running mate.
item.description: The magazine called Mr. Trump the “president of the divided states of America” and named Hillary Clinton its runner-up.
item.dc:creator: ERIN McCANN

item.title: What in the World: Who Haunts U.K. Ghost Trains? Railway Enthusiasts
item.media:description: Why do “ghost trains” operate? Believe it or not, it’s a money-saving strategy for railroad companies in Britain.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lena Bush; Photo by Antonio Mingot
item.description: The trains, bureaucratic curiosities that run infrequently and visit forgotten stations, are a draw for railroad fans, who try to ride as many as possible.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: Peter Vaughan, Maester Aemon in ‘Game of Thrones,’ Dies at 93
item.media:description: Peter Vaughan, left, with John Bradley in “Game of Thrones.”
item.description: Mr. Vaughan had an acting career in films and British television for more than 50 years before his turn as the blind mentor to Jon Snow in the HBO series.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL E. SLOTNIK

item.title: Dating With a Disability
item.media:description: Tabitha Estrellado maneuvers her wheelchair to greet friends at Blackthorn 51, a rock club in Queens, N.Y.
item.description: Women with disabilities often begin to date much later in life, and they struggle in a dating culture that places a premium on physical appearance.
item.dc:creator: WENDY LU

item.title: Anna Kendrick: The First Time I Made a Movie (at 16)
item.media:description: Anna Kendrick is the author of the memoir “Scrappy Little Nobody” (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster). This is an edited excerpt from the book.
item.description: When Ms. Kendrick, a former child actress on New York stages, was cast in the film “Camp,” it proved eye-opening about the craft and the industry.
item.dc:creator: ANNA KENDRICK

item.title: Still Processing: ‘Big Social’ and Facebook’s Moral Core
item.description: Mike Isaac, a New York Times technology reporter, joins to talk about Facebook’s decision to comply with Chinese censorship regulations.
item.dc:creator: WESLEY MORRIS and JENNA WORTHAM

item.title: The Neediest Cases: In Debt, but Undaunted
item.media:description: Natasha Bell with her daughters Aziya McEachron, 10, left, and Anyla McEachron, 7, at their home.
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.description: Natasha Bell has worked many jobs, trying to piece together financial security for her family. After living in a shelter, she now has a home, but still has debts to pay.
item.dc:creator: JOHN OTIS
item.category: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
